Appendix:
For more information on NanoString® GeoMx technology, visit [**our website**](https://www.nanostring.com/products/geomx-digital-spatial-profiler/geomx-dsp-overview/).

Details of the performance of GeoMx Whole Transcriptome Atlas (WTA) have been [**published**](https://doi.org/10.1101/2021.09.29.462442).

Minerva is an open-source software package that was developed by Laboratory of Systems Pharmacology at Harvard University and is available [**here**](https://github.com/labsyspharm/minerva-story/wiki). We would like to thank Jeremy Muhlich and John Thomas Hoffer for assistance in enabling Minerva features to support the Spatial Organ Atlas.

Stories.Description:
Welcome to the [**Spatial Organ Atlas (SOA)**](https://www.nanostring.com/spatial-organ-atlas) Mouse Brain Demonstration.

The SOA is a database for whole transcriptome spatial profiles of functional components of tissues from human and mouse generated with the GeoMx® Digital Spatial Profiler using the Whole Transcriptome Atlas (WTA). All the data in the SOA is downloadable, including [**this mouse brain sample (#004)**](https://www.nanostring.com/products/geomx-digital-spatial-profiler/spatial-organ-atlas/mouse-brain/).

Using [**Minerva**](https://github.com/labsyspharm/minerva-story/wiki), we will show you how the imaging and molecular data combine to give you a comprehensive profile of the tissue architecture and biology.

Click around to explore on your own. 

Hints:
* Zoom and pan the image via the mouse/trackpad. Dependent on browser and operating system, keyboard shortcuts are available: + zoom in, - zoom out, pan via arrow keys (tested on Chrome).
* Open and close the left- and right-hand menus by clicking on < or >.
* See results in the left-hand menu and click on the selectable regions to zoom to the featured area of the tissue.
* Turn channels on and off with the right-hand menu.

Waypoints.Name: Gross Brain Morphology
Waypoints.Description:
The brain is arguably the most complex organ in the mouse, containing an estimated 100 million cells, comprised of approximately 70 million neural cells and 30 million glial cells [**(Erö et al 2018)**](https://doi.org/10.3389/fninf.2018.00084). These cells are organized into 461 three-dimensional (3D) structures as recognized by the [**Allen Mouse Brain Atlas**](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cell.2020.04.007).

We collected data from 21 distinct areas of the mouse brain. Some of these areas were segmented into neuronal nuclei antigen-positive (NeuN+) and neuropil (including most glial cells in the neuropil segments), leading to 33 distinct regional data sets - all of which are available for [**download**](https://nanostring.com/products/geomx-digital-spatial-profiler/spatial-organ-atlas/mouse-brain/). In this Minerva Story, we will concentrate on analyzing the cortex (see section 6, Cortex Morphology), while also highlighting multiple ways to utilize data from the other regions profiled.

If you select a region on the cartoon below, the region will be highlighted on the SOA image.

The major brain areas shown here are as follows:
* Cortex
* Hippocampus
* Thalamus
* Hypothalamus
* Caudoputamen
* Amygdala

This coronal section of formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) adult mouse was visualized with antibodies to:
* NeuN (neuronal nuclei and perinuclear cytoplasm)
* GFAP (astrocytes)
* Iba1 (microglia)
* SYTO83 (nuclei)

With GeoMx DSP, regions of interest (ROIs) are selected by the user and then molecularly profiled within each ROI. These ROIs can be either profiled in the selected area (i.e., geometric profiling) or subdivided based on the visible morphology markers into compartments and profiled separately (i.e., segmented profiling). For the segmented profiling, we used NeuN as a morphology marker to segment the neuronal nuclei and neuropil regions on this sample:
* Neuronal nuclei - NeuN+
* Neuropil - NeuN-

The neuropil segments captured contain axons, dendrites, and glial cells. To see examples of segmentation by cell type, visit the [**SOA human brain data**](https://nanostring.com/products/geomx-digital-spatial-profiler/spatial-organ-atlas/human-brain/).
Waypoints.Footer:
Hints:
* You can toggle the molecularly profiled ROIs by clicking on the respective data layers (left-hand side of the screen).
* Because of the large number of ROIs, there is a new category, “All data layers”. Selecting this category allows you to toggle between selecting all data layers and selecting no data layers. A single click can unselect all data layers, allowing easy selection of a single data layer (If any layers are unselected, the first click will select all layers, the second click will unselect all).
* You can change the displayed morphology markers by selecting Channel Groups (right-hand side of the screen) - all markers or individual markers can be displayed. Switching to an individual marker can make it easier to see small or complex ROIs.

Waypoints.Name: Linking Molecular and Imaging Data
Waypoints.Description:
One of the key aspects of spatial biology is the ability to link molecular data to spatial (image) information. In this plot, the number of genes detected per ROI by each brain structure is shown. Select a data point within the plot to see its corresponding ROI in the SOA image.

Most regions in the brain show a high number of expressed genes. As expected, the segmented profiling revealed that considerably more genes were expressed in the cell body regions (NeuN+) than in the neuropil (NeuN-) regions. While the bulk of neuronal transcripts are captured in the NeuN+ somata, it is important to realize that neuropil data represents a combination of transcripts from enmeshed glia and the locally translated mRNAs of neuronal axons and dendrites.
Waypoints.Footer:
Hints:
* Select a single data point in the graph to spot the corresponding ROI in the SOA image.

axis.labelExpr: datum.label == 1 ? 'Amygdala' : datum.label == 2 ? 'Amygdala - NeuN+' : datum.label == 3 ? 'Amygdala - Neuropil' : datum.label == 4 ? 'Caudoputamen' : datum.label == 5 ? 'Caudoputamen - NeuN+' : datum.label == 6 ? 'Caudoputamen - Neuropil' : datum.label == 7 ? 'Cortex' : datum.label == 8 ? 'Cortex - NeuN+' : datum.label == 9 ? 'Cortex - Neuropil' : datum.label == 10 ? 'Epithalamus' : datum.label == 11 ? 'Hippocampus' : datum.label == 12 ? 'Hypothalamus' : datum.label == 13 ? 'Corticospinal tract' : datum.label == 14 ? 'Thalamus' : datum.label == 15 ? 'Choroid plexus' : null

Waypoints.Name: Global Cell Type Deconvolution
Waypoints.Description:
Here we are measuring the relative abundance of different cell types within each ROI using a cell type deconvolution algorithm to align our spatial data with single-cell RNA-seq from a comparable microdissection experiment. The cell-type descriptions are adapted from the source data [**(Saunders et al.)**](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cell.2018.07.028). In this graph, each row is a single area of illumination (AOI), and each brain structure (ROI category, shown on the left column of each row) has a unique composition of cell types (shown by cell type-specific colors in each row). As expected, choroid plexus AOIs show markedly distinct cell composition compared to AOIs within the parenchyma. ROIs placed in the white matter corticospinal tract show enrichment of oligodendrocytes and polydendrocytes (NG2 cells), while NeuN+ segments show clear enrichment of neurons across all regions segmented.

The deconvolution matrix was constructed as described in the R-package referenced in the paper [**Danaher P, Kim Y et al.**](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-022-28020-5) using the [**Saunders et al.**](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cell.2018.07.028) data.
Waypoints.Footer:
Hint:
* Select a single row of the figure to spot the corresponding ROI in the SOA image.

Waypoints.Name: Spatial Mapping of Segmented ROIs
Waypoints.Description: Whole transcriptome profiling using GeoMx DSP allows us to spatially map functional gene pathways and gene sets in addition to individual genes. This heatmap of the single-sample gene set enrichment analysis (ssGSEA) scores shows the relative expression of related gene sets in the NeuN+ and neuropil segments in the cortex, caudoputamen, and amygdala with a notable enrichment of glial cell gene sets in the NeuN- neuropil. The enrichment of genes related to chromatin modification and mRNA splicing in NeuN+ segments also supports reported differences in DNA methylation patterns [**(Kessler et al. 2016)**](https://doi.org/10.1093/hmg/ddv459), histone modifications [**(Zhu et al. 2021)**](https://doi.org/10.1038/s41592-021-01060-3), and alternative splicing [**(Zhang et al. 2014)**](https://doi.org/10.1523/JNEUROSCI.1860-14.2014) between neuronal and non-neuronal cells in both mouse and human brains. Glutamatergic and GABAergic synapse-related gene sets show enrichment in both NeuN+ and neuropil AOIs, with the strongest expression in the cortex. By contrast, genes related to serotonergic synapse modulation are clearly enriched in neuropil AOIs compared to the NeuN+ somata.
Waypoints.Footer:
Hint:
* Select a single column of the heatmap to spot the corresponding ROI in the SOA image.

values.type: Cortical layer II/III - Neuropil,Cortical layer IV - Neuropil,Cortical layer IV - Neuropil,Cortical layer V - Neuropil,Cortical layer VI - Neuropil,Amygdala - Neuropil,Caudoputamen - Neuropil
Cortical layer II/III - NeuN+,Caudoputamen - NeuN+,Cortical layer V - NeuN+,Cortical layer IV - NeuN+,Cortical layer VI - NeuN+,Amygdala - NeuN+,Caudoputamen - NeuN+

Waypoints.Name: Cortex Anatomy
Waypoints.Description: The [**cortex**](https://www.brainwiki.org/index.php?t=mouse&b=isocortex) is one of the most complex structure in the brain and is responsible for a wide variety of functions, including initiation of motor activity, perception of sensory information, and memory. The cortex is cytoarchitecturally divided into six layers (I through VI), though layers II/III are combined for analysis of mouse brain. Layers I through IV form localized intracortical connections. Layers V and VI form projections to subcortical targets and to the opposite hemisphere. Despite the clear structural organization of these layers, the functional physiology of how the cortical layers work in concert to drive both perceptions and behaviors is not well understood [**(Adesnik & Naka, 2018)**](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuron.2018.10.032). We collected the transcriptomic data from layers II/III-VI individually, both employing geometric regions and NeuN segmented regions. Given the unique composition of layer I, only geometric regions were selected for data collection from this layer.
Waypoints.Footer:
Hint:
* Select a structure in the cartoon to see a representative ROI on the SOA image.

Waypoints.Name: Segregation within Cortical Layers
Waypoints.Description: When we perform a principal component analysis (PCA) of cortical layer ROIs, it is observed that the first component captures 26% of the variance, while the second component only captures 6%. The first principal component separates AOIs by cellular composition, clearly showing the distinction amongst geometric (unsegmented), NeuN+, and neuropil regions. Cortical layer I is separate from other geometric regions due to the low neuronal content compared to other layers.
Waypoints.Footer:
Hint:
* Select an individual data point on the graph to spot the corresponding ROI in the SOA image.

Waypoints.Name: Cortical Cell Type Deconvolution
Waypoints.Description:
Here we are measuring the relative abundance of different cell types within the ROIs of each cortical layer using a [**cell type deconvolution algorithm**](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-022-28020-5). In this graph, each row is a single ROI, and each brain structure (ROI category, shown on the left column of each row) has a unique composition of cell types (shown by cell type specific colors in each row). It is important to note that the chart is displaying the fraction of cell types, not the absolute number. Thus, cortical layer I results show the proportion of cells that compose the ROIs of that layer.

As previously described [**(Codeluppi et al. 2018)**](https://doi.org/10.1038/s41592-018-0175-z), the proportion of neurons is lower and the proportion of non-neuronal cells is higher in cortical layer I relative to other cortical layers. This pattern is directly observable in the ROIs on the SOA image, with very few NeuN+ cells visible in layer I.

Differences between other cortical layers are more subtle but it should be noted that there is a distinct pattern in the proportion of oligodendrocytes (denoted in brown in the stacked barplots). Proportionally fewer oligodendrocytes are identified in upper cortical layers, which is consistent with reports that the highest numbers of oligodendrocytes in rodent cortex are found in layers V/VI [**(Tan et al. 2009**](https://doi.org/10.1002/glia.20826), [**Belgard et al. 2011)**](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuron.2011.06.039), whereas pyramidal neurons are more likely to have contiguous myelin sheaths than layers II/III [**(Tomassy et al. 2014)**](https://doi.org/10.1126/science.1249766).
Waypoints.Footer:
Hints:
* Select a single row of the figure to spot the corresponding ROI in the SOA image.
* Mouse over a bar in the plot to see the names of deconvoluted cell types.

Waypoints.Name: Comparing Gene Expression in Cortical Layers
Waypoints.Description: Spatially resolved whole transcriptome data of GeoMx DSP allows us to understand differential gene expression within the context of the tissue environment. In this heatmap, we have analyzed the differential gene expression between geometric regions in the cortex and have shown that markers for cortical layers are found in expected locations. For instance, *Cux1* and *Cux2* are primarily expressed by pyramidal neurons of the upper layers (II-IV) [**(Nieto et al. 2004)**](https://doi.org/10.1002/cne.20322) of the murine cortex as shown. Additionally, the expression of transcription factor *Etv1* is specific to cortical layer V, where it is known to mark a subset of pyramidal neurons in that layer [**(Doyle et al. 2008)**](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cell.2008.10.029).
Waypoints.Footer:
Hint:
* Select a single column of the heatmap to spot the corresponding ROI in the SOA image.

Waypoints.Name: Validating Cortical Gene Expression with Protein Expression
Waypoints.Description:
We have explored the relationship between the gene expression patterns we observe for the characterized layer-specific genes. We have focused here on the expression of *Ighm* (Immunoglobulin heavy constant mu), a gene specific to cortical layer VI as reported by [**Belgard et al.**](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3163272/) and identified in [**large-scale *in situ* hybridization projects**](https://doi.org/10.1038/nature05453). The normalized expression for each layer is shown for both segmented (NeuN+ and neuropil) and geometric regions, showing the layer VI-specific expression of *Ighm*. Download the full dataset to explore the expression patterns of other targets shown by [**Belgard et al.**](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3163272/)

![image](img/geneExpressionBelgardeCroppedArtBoard.png)

[*Image credit: Belgard, et al.*](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3163272/)
Waypoints.Footer:
Hint:
* Select an individual data point on the graph to spot the corresponding ROI in the SOA image.

axis.labelExpr: datum.label == 1 ? 'Layer I' : datum.label == 2 ? 'Layer II/III' : datum.label == 3 ? 'Layer IV' : datum.label == 4 ? 'Layer V' : datum.label == 5 ? 'Layer VI' : null

Waypoints.Name: Differential Gene Expression
Waypoints.Description: The diversity of neuron function and physiology coupled with the enormous structural complexity and compartmentalization of the brain is an arduous challenge for functional neurogenomics. By directly comparing gene expression between neuron populations in two anatomical locations of interest, we can identify spatial gene expression patterns related to functional behavior. This volcano plot of the differential gene expression between NeuN+ segments in the amygdala and caudoputamen allows us to directly compare the gene expression levels in neurons from the two adjacent anatomical regions with divergent connectivity and function. The expression of the excitatory synaptic regulator *C1ql3* in neurons of the basolateral amygdala, for example, has been shown to be required for normal fear memories [**(Martinelli et al. 2016)**](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuron.2016.07.002), while genes linked to dopamine transmission in the striatum including *Rgs9*, *Drd2*, *Adora2a*, *Gpr88* mediate locomotion and addiction related behaviors [**(Rahman et al. 2003**](https://doi.org/10.1016/S0896-6273(03)00321-0), [**Navendar et al. 2021)**](https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-021-88363-9).
Waypoints.Footer:
Hint:
* Select the regions on the graph with the genes that are differentially expressed to see all the ROIs where the genes are more highly expressed.

Waypoints.Name: Gene Expression Across Neuron-Rich ROIs
Waypoints.Description:
As shown in the Differential Gene Expression section (Section 11), the caudoputamen indicates clear enrichment of markers for D1 and D2 striatal medium spiny neurons, including *Drd2*, *Adora2a*, *Penk*, *Tac1*, and *Pdyn*. In this example from the [**GENSAT project**](http://gensat.org/), the expression pattern of *Drd2* can be seen only in the caudoputamen in a matching coronal plain. This observation is replicated in the region-specific gene expression data of GeoMx DSP.

![image](img/Drd2_ADULT.jpg)

[**Source: The Gene Expression Nervous System Atlas (GENSAT) Project, NINDS Contracts N01NS02331 & HHSN271200723701C to The Rockefeller University (New York, NY).**](http://gensat.org/imagenavigator.jsp?imageID=48609)
Waypoints.Footer:
Hint:
* Select an individual data point on the graph to spot the corresponding ROI in the SOA image.
